titleStmt.title: Description of Bryn Mawr College Library, MS 48: De nobilitate, etc.
titleStmt.funder: Council on Library and Information Resources

notesStmt.note: Faye, C.U., continued and edited by W.H. Bond, Supplement to the Census of Medieval and Renaissance Manuscripts in the United States and Canada (New York: Bibliographical Society of America, 1962), p. 399, no. 51.

Kristeller, P. O., Iter Italicum; a finding list of uncatalogued or incompletely catalogued humanistic manuscripts of the Renaissance in Italian and other libraries (London, 1963-97), vol. 5, p. 351, no. 51.
Ullman, B.L. Petrarch Manuscripts in the United States (Padova, 1964) p. 460.
Dutschke, Dennis. Census of Petrarch Manuscripts in the United States (Padua, 1986), p. 219, no. 88.

msContents.summary: This humanistic manuscript was copied on parchment in Italy in the mid-fifteenth century. The first four works are three letters of Poggio Bracciolini, including one on nobility and one against avarice, and a poem by Carlo Marsuppino (Aretino) on nobility; these share a page layout, illuminated initials, and marginal notes of proper names in red. Three brief letters by Petrarch and an Easter table have been added at the end (fols. 103v-114r) and have spaces left for illuminated initials. Manicules and marginal annotations by multiple readers appear throughout.

msItem.title: Poggio Bracciolini, De nobilitate
msItem.explicit: ... de ambulandum extra oppidum censeo uisendumque fluuium quem iste nobis sepius ob fertilitatem piscium laudauit. [fol. 38v]

msItem.title: Epistola poggii florentini ad insignem virum d. Gregorium Corarium sedis ap[osto]lice Prothonotarium
msItem.incipit: Poggius Plurimam salutem dicit viro insigni gregorio Corario sedis apostolicae prothonotario. [fol. 38v]
msItem.explicit: ... et suauissimis moribus conuenire uideatur. Vale et me ut facis ama. florentie die octauo aprilis 1440. [fol. 43v]

msItem.title: Caroli arentini de nobilitate carmen
msItem.incipit: Quid sit nobilitas scribere liberis / Temptas quod pedibus tolle[re] du[m] cupis ... [fol. 43v]
msItem.explicit: Vltra quas possuit durior hercules / Metas nauigiis est male peruium. [fol. 46r]

msItem.title: Ad clarissimum virum franciscum barbarum Poggii florentini contra auaritiam
msItem.incipit: Qvoniam plures mortalium mi francisce non uiuunt sed agunt uitam ... [fol. 48r]
msItem.explicit: Sed cum satis collocuti simus et nox superuenerit abeundum censeo. Ita omnes consurrexerunt. [fol. 102v]

msItem.title: Epistola francisci petrarce ad fratrem Iohannem de colonnia
msItem.incipit: [A]nilem tibi fabulam, sed ex re ut flaccus ait garrio. Aranea iter agens, forte obuiam habuit podagram, et quo inquit tam mesta proficisceris. [fol. 103v]
msItem.explicit: . . . quo inde si pellere uis podagram pelle delitias, si malum omne uis pellere pelle diuitias et uale ad fontem forgie xo kal[endis] Julias. [fol. 105v]

msItem.title: Ad Clementem sextum Romanorum pontificem fugiendam medicorum turbam, epistola eiusdem
msItem.incipit: [F]ebris tue nuntius p[ate]r beatissime tremorem membris meis [et] horrorem attulit nec id circo blandi loquens aut similis dicar illi de quo satiricus ait. [fol. 106r]
msItem.explicit: ... spem bonam ac [letum] animum habeto, si te, si nos [o]mnes, si t[ecum e]grotantem ecclesiam saluam cupis ... [date effaced?; fol. 107v]

msItem.title: Epistola francisci petrarce poete Revocatio amici a periculosis amoribus
msItem.incipit: [V]erba michi nunc metus ac dolor eliciunt. Alterum sine altero forsam tacitus tulissem ... [fol. 108v]
msItem.explicit: Qui et ubi sim nosti quod te moneam intelligis quid de te metuam uides. uale caue circumspice. [fol. 113r]

supportDesc.extent: 114+i; 222 x 152 mm bound to 232 x 165 mm
supportDesc.foliation: Modern foliation in pencil, upper right recto

p.signatures: Quires 1-11 signed a-i, k-l, in modern pencil, lower right first recto

p.catchwords: Horizontal catchwords in lower margin varying from the center to right of center

layoutDesc.layout: Single column of twenty-one lines (fols. 1r-105v) or twenty-two to twenty-three lines (fols. 106r-113r); ruled with faint vertical bounding lines in hard point with a double vertical bounding line on the left and a single on the right in ink; remains of pricking in right margin; written area: 136 x 90 mm

decoDesc.decoNote: Six three- or four-line illuminated initials with marginal foliate and floral extensions marking text divisions (fols. 1r, 3r, 38v, 43v, 48r, 50r) in the first four works of the volume; partial illuminated border with blue shield, its device effaced, in lower margin of opening page (fol. 1r); partial illuminated border with pink flowers from a gold urn in lower margin of the opening page of the fourth work (fol. 48r); at the end of the manuscript, spaces for decorative initials left unfilled, guide letters for decorator visible (fols. 103v, 106r, 108v); table in red and black (fol. 114r); rubricated in red throughout; marginalia in red or black throughout
Inside front coverBookplate, Phyllis Walter Goodhart
Inside front coverBookplate, Bryn Mawr College Library, "From the library of Phyllis Goodhart Gordon '35"
1rIlluminated initial N with marginal foliate extensions with owl
3rIlluminated initial N with marginal foliate extensions
38vIlluminated initial P with marginal foliate extensions
43vIlluminated initial Q with marginal foliate extensions
48rIlluminated initial Q with marginal foliate extensions
50rIlluminated initial C with marginal floral extensions

history.provenance: Written in Italy in the middle of the fifteenth century; in the library of Phyllis Goodhart Gordan (bookplate) and John Dozier Gordan, Jr.; her bequest to Bryn Mawr College in 1995 (bookplate)
